issues.text: whether the power of exemption conferred upon the Union Government violates Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f)(g) of the Constitution on the ground that it is uncontrolled and unguided

anchor.surface_text: On those pleadings and on the arguments at the Bar, the following points arise for decision in this case, namely, whether the power of exemption conferred upon the Union Government violates Arts. 14 and 19 1  f   g  of the Constitution on the ground that it is uncontrolled and unguided,

issues.text: whether, assuming that the power is not unconstitutional, the exemption granted by the notifications, aforesaid, is in excess of the power granted by r. 8

anchor.surface_text: and  2  whether, assuming that the power is number unconstitutional, the exemption granted by the numberifications, aforesaid, is in excess of the power granted by r. 8. Before discussing the vires of the law,

issues.text: whether r. 8 of the Central Excise Rules, 1944 vests unguided power and constitutes excessive delegation violating Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f)(g)

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that r. 8 of the Central Excise Rules, 1944, under the Act, vests the Government with unguided power wholly or partially to exempt any goods from the duty leviable under the Act,

holdings.text: Rule 8 of the Central Excise Rules, 1944 is constitutional and does not constitute excessive delegation of legislative power violating Articles 14 and 19(1)(f)(g) of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 8 derives validity from s.37(2)(xvii) of the Act; provides necessary flexibility in taxation incidence; legislature best judges classes and amounts; supported by ss.12,38 and precedents like Sea Customs Act s.23.

holdings.text: The exemption notifications issued under Rule 8 are within the power conferred by the rule and do not exceed it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemptions refer to excisable goods produced by specified small producers; notifications have statutory effect under s.38; tax on production payable by producers; conditions fulfilled by society.

holdings.text: The classification between goods produced in big establishments like the petitioner Company and goods produced by small powerloom weavers in cooperative societies (with no more than four powerlooms per member) is valid under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The State has, therefore, made a valid classification between goods produced in big establishments arid similar goods produced by small powerloom weavers in the mofussil, who are usually ignorant, illiterate and poor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Protects petty, illiterate, poor small producers from competition by big mills; promotes cottage industries per Art.43; banding in cooperatives does not alter individual small-scale nature; reasonable classification with nexus to object.

holdings.text: The exemption granted to the Society does not violate Articles 14 and 19(1)(f)(g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that there is no room for the contention that there has been excessive delegation of power to exempt. It was next contended that if it were held that r. 8

holdings.reasoning_summary: Society aids individual small weavers (each <=4 looms); not equivalent to large mill; valid classification; no discrimination; promotes public interest in cottage industries.

holdings.text: The petition has no merit and is dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Both contentions rejected; Rule 8 and notifications valid and constitutional; no violation of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that there is numbermerit in this petition.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition challenging Rule 8 of Central Excise Rules, 1944 and notifications exempting cooperative society dismissed as having no merit; exemption upheld as valid classification.
